awd_titl_txt: AF: Collaborative Research: Robustness of Topological Quantum Memories
awd_abstract_narration:
Computers permeate all socio-economic activities of our times. The limitations of our present silicon-based computational power are no longer residing in the far future. The topic of this award is one that is relevant to finding new directions for future computation, while at the same time enlarging our understanding of physical systems suitable for quantum computing. The research will address fundamental science questions, such as whether topological states of matter can store, at non-zero temperatures, quantum (qubit) or classical (bit) elements of information. The research activities will be accompanied by educational efforts at three different levels: The PIs will provide solid education and training to graduate students in the field of quantum information; they will develop undergraduate courses at the interface between physics and computer science; and they will use their expertise to help develop the "Future of Information" module for techCAMP, a program directed towards middle-school and high-school teachers.

Encoding information in topological states of certain many-particle systems has been proposed as robust way to store quantum information. In these systems, the ground state is not unique and its multiplicity is not altered by local perturbations. As a result, when used to encode information, topological qubits are less susceptible to errors than standard qubits. Although protected from static perturbations, it is still uncertain how effective topological quantum memories are in the presence of dynamical perturbations. The proposed research addresses two important aspects of this issue. The first concerns the study of loss of coherence in realistic setups, where both equilibrium and non-equilibrium noise must be considered. The second is whether topological quantum memories in the presence of thermal fluctuations are attainable in physically realizable systems. Building on these investigations, the goal is to find ways to improve fault tolerance in topological quantum information processing.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This projec had two main outcomes.

First, we demonstrated that the surface code, an important class of topological quantum memories, is fault tolerant under realistic physical enviroments. Our demonstration relies on a developing physical model for how the quantum systems forming the surface code connects to its surrounding environment. As a result of this connection, the environment induces errors in the code that hamper its ability to preserve information. More importantly, these errors tend to correlated to each other when they originate from a environment that also behaves quantum mechanically. Our calculations shows that even in the presence of these correlated errors, it is still possible for the surface code to work well, as long as the connection to the environment is not too strong. Previously, it was unclear how damaging these correlated errors might be. This result has important implications for those who seek to build topological quantum computers.

Second, we have developed a way to use matrix products and tensor networks to solve difficult computational problems, such as searching databases and finding data configurations that satisfy a large number of constraints. This new technique relies on representing bits as matrices and allows for parallel computations without the need of multiprocessing.

A minor outcome of this project, which is currently being explored by the PI and his collaborators, is the realization that quantum entanglement is a powerful tool for probing the physics of complex quantum systems, such as those needed to build quantum computers. For instance, how can one tell if it is easy or not to reverse the evolution in time of a complicated system (i.e., the equivalent of putting humpty dumpty together)? Sometimes appearances are deceiving and something that looked very difficult may turn out to be straightforward. It turns out that the entanglement spectrum, a set of numbers that can be readily obtained from the wave function of the system, contains information about this and other interesting properties.

This project involved two graduate and two undergraduate students, all trained in cutting-edge interdisciplinary science.


Last Modified: 07/31/2015
Modified by: Eduardo Mucciolo
